comments.commentBody: No mention of the fact that the family does not need to worry about the cost of these children's health care. If they lived in the States, financial concerns would likely overwhelm other considerations of the parents as they attempt to provide a good life for all their children.
How the Giants beat the 49ers to get to the SB was also about the permanent things.

Good lord these people complaining about Fox are wimps. The fact that this match was on "free" TV and hi-def in the U.S. is a miracle. Anyone in their 30's and up will remember how difficult it was to see good club soccer 10 years ago. Great match. It always seemed like SAF's reliance on the old guard would be his downfall ..including bringing on Scholes? Giggs played a part in Rooney's goal but he was invisible 90% of the match.

Given the fact that these girls live in Canada it is likely that their basic needs will always be met. The family doesn't need to pursue a reality tv contract. A little water in the sippy cup instead of juice will help to ensure better oral hygiene for the future. They are wonderful and special little girls who clearly have the love and support of a large, extended family.

Um... no one has mentioned the fact that it is a night scene, something Michelangelo avoided in his paintings and frescoes almost entirely (I say this because I'm not near my library and can't be 100% certain he NEVER did a night scene without checking). I have not read Forcellino's book so I don't know if he comments about it being a night scene, or if any other scholar has written about that aspect. So that right off the bat is troubling.

What I see as I gaze at it is that the execution is labored, the palette is garish and harsh (even for the Mannerist era), the figures are awkward in relation to one another as if they were created separately and pasted on, the spatial construct is flattened and without convincing depth, proportions are off (note the exaggeration of the scale of the Virgin's head vis-à-vis the drawing), her foot is out of proportion to her body (and the drawing), the head of Christ is just plain awkwardly painted while the trunk is overworked, the light source is not consistent (note the face of the angel in rose then look at the face of the Virgin- where are the corresponding highlights on her mask-like face?), and the sparse vegetation in the oddly red turf (too randomly placed for a master), and the über-disegno quality to the rendering.

A swing and a miss! It's a game little copy, but a copy.

I'm with # 20 above. And I can even agree with the fine article. With budget deficits at $1.4 trillion per year, the Administrations promise to try hard to reduce medicare spending by $200 billion over 10 years seems very close to "Ruling out long-term entitlement spending restraint".

An article on Iowahawk did the math on "the rich".
http://iowahawk.typepad.com/iowahawk/2011/03/feed-your-family-on-10-bill...

Total income of households in excess of $250k (G - E*$250,000) = $1.412 trillion

That is a 100% tax on everything over Obama's definition of "the rich", and it can barely close the budget deficit this year. Next year, well, having drained the rich completely, the haul won't be nearly as lucrative. so then what?
If what you are saying is that some inflation is the better alternative to where we are today; I agree. Sometimes you talk to much economiceeze.
Oh, just stop being right all the time, OK?

Lets first roll back to National Health Care and the single payor.  Why did President Obama seemingly give this away?  Also, why don't we overturn legislation that makes it illegal for the Federal Government to bargain for Rx prices with big pharma?  Were both of these to be the starting line the dust cloud would be out of the picture or maybe a great deal smaller.  Imagine the sky above Iceland and that volcanic spewing travelling east into airspace used for avation.  Unlike the volcano the health care dust cloud is of our own making.  This could have been a large part of the "change" America was looking for.  And still the U. S. is barely in the running among nations when measuring health care for all.

La di dah, PK waves his hands and tells us that the key problem isn't public debt it's private debt. Um, maybe it's both? So he has us looking at a chart of private debt to GDP, when it would seem what's important is (private + public debt) to GDP. And what would *that* chart show? Well, it's still going up! So if debt to GDP is a problem, the US has a bigger problem now than before.

So, after the U.S. has had 0 rates for three years, two bouts of quantitative easing, and huge budget deficits north of 10% of GDP and - the rate of debt, public and private, to GDP continues to go up. Normally, when a course of action is tried again and again and isn't successful, a rational person will decide that the action doesn't work. But PK has his theory so he knows what's what, and so his answer is always that the failed course of action must not only continue but be accentuated. I guess in the game of economics, the winner is the one who doesn't concede he's wrong; and sadly PK doesn't care about being right, he just intends to win.

It's not a "can't do spirit" but a conscious DECISION to not worry about the less fortunate in society and around the globe. As governmental austerity takes hold in most of the industrialized world--especially in America after Obama-Biden-McConnell-Boehner make their "grand bargains" of 2011--the young, the sick, the disabled, the unemployed and the poor will suffer. The "haves" and the "have yachts" will do anything but suffer. That's not a "can't do" spirit. It's a political decision to comfort the comfortabel in order to hit them up for campaign contributions and future jobs (see former senator Gregg announcing yesterday that's he's now going to work for Goldman Sachs).
Why does Paul Krugman keep pretending that the anybody in politics (especially Obama who ran, remember, on "hope and change") cares about anything but their next political campaign and future jobs in the private sector once their out of office? How much more obvious do politicians have to make things to PK before he stops complaining about just Republicans and excoriates America's entire political class?
Earlier today PK stated that the GOP's opposition cannot have an adult discussion with Republicans on economic matters, let alone find positions of compromise. What opposition? There's no political debate taking place in this country on economic issues. The GOP moves the goal posts further to the right each year with Obama and the Democrats trailing merrily behind. Gary Gensler, Obama's appointee to head the CFTC, won't even establish guidelines to curb speculation in oil prices as he was required to do by January of 2011 by Dodd-Frank. Bernie Sanders thinks the CFTC is now breaking the law. Does anyone actually think Obama cares about any of this?

How I think it's going? As I predicted - not a "V"; not a "U"; but an "L" with a long bottom leg, tilted slightly such that it is slightly upwards, and that bottom leg is very raggedy, with ups and downs.

It's a long de-leveraging process, with housing, an important sector, hobbled for some time.

I don't think there is any magic fix in this, other than to take steps to assure we do not slip into actual deflation.

Having once toiled in Business Week's fertile garden back in the days when it was touting Arthur Laffer as the best new thing since canned peaches, I've realised at a young and tender age not to put too much stock in its economic analysis. It does a mostly fine job on reporting about companies or industries - what they're doing right or wrong, and why - but when it comes to covering matters of economic policy it has a poor track record of being even close to correct.
How do I think its going?  I think you're right and Paulson's still a billionaire.

That is kind of a leading question. Let's face it, an economist must wear a turban and a glittered jump suit. In the HBO special "Too Big to Fail," Ben Bernanke asks Hank Paulson if he thinks the banks will lend the Tarp money. "Of course they will," he replied. A lot of people will say this person or that person is a genius because they measure their intelligence by their bank accounts. But because economists are called upon to predict future events and because it is virtually impossible to do so I have a proven strategy which bore out with crystal clarity last Thursday at Belmont; don't bet on the races. If you don't find that example compelling just look at the guy who paid two hundred million dollars for a season ticket to Citi Field. Balance your portfolio, take profits when you get them and buy the ebook "The Black Swan." Good luck.

http://shrvl.com/6bp2x

The economy is still weak.  I believe that it will continue to be weak as long as business leaders keep harping on and on that the only solution is lower corporate taxes, and lower payroll taxes.  It completely ignores the other have of the market place, which is the consumer.  No well paying jobs = No spending.

Macroeconomic policy has not been exhausted. The stimulus plan in the U.S. was simply a minimus plan. Shovel ready projects got shelved by cuts at the state level and a lot of federal infrastructure money in the stimulus plan got moved to repair and maintenance projects.

Let's try a really big stimulus plan coordinated with sound policies like making mortgage loans easier to obtain. If that fails maybe we could then say we have a structural problem.

It really is hard to accept that the medicine prescribed by macroeconomics has failed when it has yet to be administered in a proper dosage.

http://www.escapethenewgreatdepression.com

I'm betting on the Second Law of Thermodynamics as applied to economic and social systems, to wit: There are many more ways to screw things up than to do them correctly, so the most probable outcome is that they'll be screwed up.

The Cambridge number theorist G.H. Hardy put it best: "When the world is mad, a mathematician may find in mathematics an incomparable anodyne." Here's to calculus.

The trajectories of human character and judgment are no more variable than any other grouping of trajectories.

The trajectories of Bloomberg Business Week's usual forecasts are where they should be: the gullible buy the snake-oil of BBW just as expected (and intended by the business community, otherwise why have such a shill in your pocket).

You economists are little more than gnats at a picnic who sometimes turn out to be more substantial, which is when they move the picnic.

Now where did I put my teeth?.

I think we find ourselves at a critical juncture. The only way to get past this macroeconomic myopia that seems to spread with each passing day is to find some appealing figure to spread the message. Perhaps a WWE wrestler. Maybe even a NASCAR driver. A face in the crowd, as it were.

The OPRPs* are getting me down with their debt rhetoric. Their argument is contradicted by the old adage: "You can't sell from an empty cart." And that remains where we are right now.

*OPRP = otherwise perfectly reasonable people

As you repeatedly point out: so many important people are so very terribly wrong about so many things.  How does this happen?  Where do these people, and their ideas, come from?  I think to address this problem, and others like it, we must root out the source of the problem.  Our system of higher education has become a joke.  Colleges and Universities today are little more than baby-sitting services for kids we'd like to keep out the workforce long enough that they stand some chance of showing up to work without a hangover.  Why?  Because faculty cannot fail their students.  No matter how poor their performance, we molly coddle them until they receive their diplomas, because if we didn't, we couldn't pay the bills.  Which isn't entirely true - we could pay the bills, but the profit motive now rules supreme, an actual education notwithstanding.  And with highly regarded credentials in hand, the frat boys take up positions of undue influence, and make a complete mess of everything.  One of two things must happen: either we must begin regarding degrees as the worthless pieces of paper that they are, or higher education must begin to really mean something again.

things are bad but technically there isn't "third depression" yet. housing didn't stage a recovery but bank share prices did and there was no government take over of banks, only bail-outs. in theory prof. may be right but JP probably made more money.
You have a Nobel, they don't. In this case at least, end of discussion...
It's can't do because of course bond holders must be protected.
We haven't forgotten.  But I bet the other side has forgotten long ago.  One of their weaknesses is that their memories don't retain the losses.  Also, they think the stock market is the economy.
